overview_of_class: This is the first of a two-quarter course on quantum theory. We will discuss both the meaning of the theory, and how to use it to calculate experimentally observable quantities for simple systems such as atoms, spins, light polarization, and tunneling systems.
name: Quantum Mechanics
title: WCAS PHYSICS 339-1-20 Quantum Mechanics

instructors.instructor_addr: Technological Institute (2145 Sheridan Road), Room F-325, Evanston

descriptions.name: Overview of class
descriptions.value: This is the first of a two-quarter course on quantum theory. We will discuss both the meaning of the theory, and how to use it to calculate experimentally observable quantities for simple systems such as atoms, spins, light polarization, and tunneling systems.

descriptions.name: Registration Requirements
descriptions.value: Prerequisites: second-year standing in ISP or PHYSICS 330-1 and 333-1. A strong ability to do practical calculations with calculus and familiarity with complex numbers.

descriptions.name: Learning Objectives
descriptions.value: Understand and apply the concepts related to the quantum mechanical amplitude, quantum states, superposition of quantum states, observables and operators, quantum measurement, unitary time evolution, transition amplitudes and probabilities, and symmetry and conservation laws.

descriptions.name: Class Materials (Required)
descriptions.value: J.S. Townsend, A Modern Approach to Quantum Mechanics, 2nd Edition (University Science Books, 2012)

subject: PHYSICS
